Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Intranasal Esketamine and Dexmedetomidine for Sedation in Toddlers

Trial_Design.evidence: In this prospective, double-blind, randomised controlled trial, 121 children aged 1-3 years scheduled for TTE at Hunan Children's Hospital were enrolled.

Participants.evidence: 121 children aged 1-3 years scheduled for TTE at Hunan Children's Hospital were enrolled.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive dexmedetomidine 1 mcg.kg−1 combined with esketamine 0.5 mg.kg−1 (group S1), 1 mg.kg−1 (group S2), or 1.5 mg.kg−1 (group S3).

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of different doses of intranasal esketamine combined with dexmedetomidine for sedation in toddlers undergoing transthoracic echocardiography (TTE).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the success rate of sedation, measured within 45 minutes.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding included anesthesiologists, sonographers, children, and parents.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 121 children aged 1-3 years scheduled for TTE at Hunan Children's Hospital were enrolled.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of the 121 children, 40 were analysed in group S1, 41 in group S2, and 40 in group S3.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The success rates were 60% in S1, 85.4% in S2, and 87.5% in S3 (p = 0.004).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were minimal, with one case of upper airway obstruction in S3 and four instances of oxygen desaturation, all resolving without intervention.

Funding.evidence: Supported by the Scientific Research Fund of the Hunan Medical Association and the Scientific Research Project of the Hunan Provincial Health Commission.
